newsitem.title: UK: Britain to raise prison camp claims with Japan.
newsitem.headline: Britain to raise prison camp claims with Japan.

text.p: Foreign Secretary Robin Cook will raise the plight of Britons who survived Japan's World War Two prison camps when he meets his Japanese counterpart this weekend, officials said on Friday.

Cook, in office since the Labour Party's crushing May 1 election victory, is due to have lunch with Yukihiko Ikeda on Saturday and will discuss whether Tokyo should pay more money to soldiers and civilians who were captured and sent to camps when Japanese forces overran Britain's Far East colonies.
Japan paid compensation to former prisoners under a 1951 treaty and refuses to consider demands for more, but about 12,000 Britains have been pressing for extra sums for maltreatment.
British officials say the terms of the 1951 treaty mean there can be no more formal negotiations on the subject.
"The foreign secretary will raise the issue. He would be crazy not to given the strength of feeling. We'd like to see everyone concerned happy and satisfied," a foreign office spokesman said.
The grievances of former prisoners remain a sore point in Britain's otherwise good relations with Japan, which will be reinforced next year when Emperor Akihito pays a state visit.
